item.title: S&P 500 Holds Steady in Face of Weak Data, Buoyed by Big Tech
item.description: US equities held steady Wednesday as gains in technology stocks offset weak economic data on jobs and services.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Falls as Saudi Arabia Seeks More Major Production Hikes
item.description: Oil fell on signs Saudi Arabia wants another major production increase, raising expectations that a glut of crude will form this year.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Cobalt Holdings Won’t Proceed With London IPO
item.description: Cobalt Holdings Plc decided not to proceed with its planned initial public offering in London.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Structures used for processing raw cobalt at a mine near Lubumbashi, the Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Banks Shop Over $1 Billion in Debt for Wingstop Franchisee
item.description: A group of Wall Street banks, led by Jefferies Financial Group Inc. and UBS Group AG, have started pre-marketing more than $1 billion of debt to fund Bain Capital’s acquisition of restaurant chain operator Sizzling Platter, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Gowri Gurumurthy, Jeannine Amodeo

media:content.media:description: A Little Caesars restaurant is seen in Bloomsburg. Photographer: SOPA Images/SOPA Images

item.title: FCA Official Emily Shepperd Departs Regulator After Four Years
item.description: The UK’s Financial Conduct Authority said Chief Operating Officer Emily Shepperd will depart after four years at the watchdog.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Surane

media:content.media:description: A sign on the window of the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) headquarters ahead of a meeting of UK bank bosses in London, UK, on Thursday, July 6, 2023. Bank bosses are meeting with a UK regulator on Thursday to talk about accusations of “profiteering” from savers. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Eyes Capital Relief for Insurers to Spur Asset-Backed Market
item.description: The European Commission is considering reducing the capital that insurers must hold against investments in asset-backed securities, part of a broader effort to revive a €1.2 trillion ($1.4 trillion) market that can finance areas like housing, energy, and defense.
item.dc:creator: Esteban Duarte, Nicholas Comfort

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of the European Commission in Brussels, Belgium.

item.title: Treasuries Rally as Weak Data Reinforce Fed Wagers: Markets Wrap
item.description: Treasuries extended this year’s surge after weaker-than-expected economic data reinforced speculation that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at least twice this year to prevent an economic recession.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: KKR Quit Thames Bid After It Saw Limited Upside to a Rescue Plan
item.description: KKR & Co. withdrew its bid to invest £4 billion ($5.4 billion) in Thames Water when the US infrastructure giant realized there was little upside to a deal, according to people familiar with the deliberations.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha, Claire Ruckin, Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Engineers' vans parked at the Thames Water South Woodford pumping station in London.

item.title: Poland’s Fiscal Woes in Focus After Tusk Ally Loses Election
item.description: The defeat of Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk’s favored presidential candidate is shifting investor focus to the nation’s troubling public finances, amid growing concerns about political stability.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko, Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Donald Tusk Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Emerging-Market Currencies Led by Korean Won Gain After US Data
item.description: Emerging-market currencies gained Wednesday as two sets of US data stoked concern over weaker growth and higher price pressures in the world’s largest economy, undermining the dollar.
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Butler, Raphael Almeida

media:content.media:description: The rising Kospi and Kosdaq indices displayed at the Korea Exchange in Seoul, on June 4.

item.title: JPMorgan Plans to Offer Clients Financing Against Crypto ETFs
item.description: JPMorgan Chase & Co. plans to let trading and wealth-management clients use some cryptocurrency-linked assets as collateral for loans, a major step by the biggest US bank to make inroads into an industry President Donald Trump has pledged to support.
item.dc:creator: Emily Nicolle, Hannah Levitt

media:content.media:description: The JP Morgan Chase & Co. headquarters in New York.

item.title: Bay Street Sees Future Cuts After Bank of Canada Holds Steady
item.description: The Bank of Canada’s decision to hold its policy interest rate at 2.75% shows that it’s more focused on core inflation than weak economic growth as it waits to get more data, according to analysts.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Shin

media:content.media:description: Tiff Macklem, governor of the Bank of Canada, during a news conference in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of Canada is warning that the ongoing tariff dispute has "rattled markets" and increases the risk of "disorderly" sell-offs that would test the country's financial system.

item.title: South Africa’s 10-Year Bond Yield Drops to Lowest Since 2022
item.description: South Africa’s 10-year government bond yield dropped below 10% for the first time in more than three years as investors bet the nation will be successful in its third attempt at corralling support for its budget.
item.dc:creator: Mpho Hlakudi

media:content.media:description: The financial district in Cape Town, South Africa.

item.title: Blue Owl’s Clark: Investors Are Pushing Consolidation
item.description: James Clarke, head of institutional business at Blue Owl Capital, says, “there’s a lot going on that has been a massive sea change in the alternative space.” with major credit firms squeezing out smaller players as investors look to consolidate relationships. He speaks with Bloomberg’s Dani Burger on the sidelines of the SuperReturn Conference in Berlin.

item.title: Gold Rallies as Weak US Data Reinforce Bets on Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: Gold rallied after weaker-than-expected US economic data reinforced speculation that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at least twice this year.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

item.title: Investors’ New Found Love of Europe Dominates SuperReturn
item.description: As investor unease lingers over the prospects for global dealmaking, money managers’ renewed interest in Europe has become a dominant theme at this year’s SuperReturn private capital conference.
item.dc:creator: Kriti Gupta, Dani Burger, Silas Brown

media:content.media:description: The Euronext NV stock exchange in Paris. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Wildfires Prompt Hudbay and Alamos Gold to Evacuate Canada Mines
item.description: Raging Canadian wildfires have forced evacuations from several mining operations as heat and wind push flames across the resource-rich western provinces.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Lorinc

media:content.media:description: Wildfire smoke above Highway 97 near Trutch, British Columbia, on May 30.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Wants More Super-Size OPEC+ Hikes
item.description: Saudi Arabia wants OPEC+ to continue with accelerated oil supply hikes in the coming months as it puts greater importance on regaining lost market share, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Fiona MacDonald

media:content.media:description: Storage tanks and oil processing facilities operate at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, on Monday, Oct. 1, 2018. Saudi Aramco aims to become a global refiner and chemical maker, seeking to profit from parts of the oil industry where demand is growing the fastest while also underpinning the kingdom’s economic diversification.

item.title: Carlyle Urging Services Firms to Ramp Up Aggression
item.description: Steve Wise, co-head of Americas corporate private equity at Carlyle, says the firm is advising its service-based companies to “lean in and be aggressive while others are retreating” amid uncertainty surrounding US Tariff policies. He speaks with Bloomberg’s Dani Burger on the sidelines of the SuperReturn Conference in Berlin.

item.title: US Firms Spared Tariffs Should Ramp Up, Carlyle’s Wise Says
item.description: Companies without direct exposure to US tariffs should use this time to be more aggressive as others retreat, according to Carlyle Group Inc.’s Steve Wise.
item.dc:creator: Meg Short, Dani Burger

media:content.media:description: An empty bed in a room at a hospital emergency room in San Diego.

item.title: Russia Behind Arson Attack Targeting Ukrainian Firm on UK Soil, Prosecutors Allege
item.description: Russian intelligence was behind an arson attack on a London warehouse supplying goods to Ukraine — including Starlink satellite equipment — prosecutors alleged at the opening of a trial against six men accused of pushing Moscow’s agenda on home soil.
item.dc:creator: Upmanyu Trivedi

item.title: Treasury Yields Slide on Fresh Evidence US Economy Is Weakening
item.description: Treasury yields declined to the lowest levels in nearly a month for most tenors after weaker-than-expected gauges of job creation and service-sector activity strengthened traders’ conviction that the Federal Reserve will resume cutting interest rates this year.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick

media:content.media:description: A server sets a table at a restaurant in San Francisco, California, US, on Monday, June 26, 2023. California led a nationwide jump in job vacancies in April that reversed recent declines and keeps pressure on the Federal Reserve to consider more interest-rate hikes. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Egypt Inflation Quickens Just as Central Bank Weighs Cuts
item.description: Egyptian inflation accelerated for a third month, exceeding estimates and potentially making the central bank more cautious in extending a monetary-easing cycle.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Old Cairo. Photographer: Islam Safwat/Bloomberg

item.title: CDL to Sell $2.1 Billion Singapore Office Site to Cut Debt
item.description: City Developments Ltd. agreed to sell its majority stake in one of Singapore’s most iconic office complexes, as the developer seeks to reduce debt and regain investor confidence after a family feud.
item.dc:creator: Dexter Low

media:content.media:description: The South Beach complex. Photographer: Lauryn Ishak/Bloomberg

item.title: Palantir Investors Unfazed by Sky-High Valuation as Stock Surges
item.description: Palantir Technologies Inc.’s breakneck rally shows no sign of letting up as investors remain captivated by its artificial intelligence promise despite one of the most expensive valuations among US stocks.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

media:content.media:description: A Palantir banner during the company's IPO at the New York Stock Exchange in 2020.

item.title: Circle IPO Is Said to Be Likely to Price Above Marketed Range
item.description: Circle Internet Group Inc.’s initial public offering is likely to price above the marketed range, after fielding orders for more than 25 times the number of shares available in the upsized deal, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The Circle logo.

item.title: Saudi IPO Draws $32 Billion In Orders After Dividend Reversal
item.description: Saudi Arabia-based Specialized Medical Co. attracted about 121 billion riyals ($32 billion) in orders for its initial public offering, following a reset of its institutional order book after the company clawed back recently paid dividends.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta

item.title: Mayfair Said to Mull Options for Property Classified Site AtHome
item.description: Mayfair Equity Partners is considering options for Luxembourg-based property classified site atHome Group after receiving interest from potential investors, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Vinicy Chan

media:content.media:description: The atHome website.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Cuts Oil Prices for Asia as OPEC+ Adds More Barrels
item.description: Saudi Aramco cut the price of its main oil grade to buyers in Asia after OPEC+ continued with its outsized output increases for a third month.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Alex Longley, Anthony Di Paola

media:content.media:description: Crude oil storage tanks at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: US Services Activity Unexpectedly Contracts in May
item.description: Activity at US service providers slipped into contraction territory for the first time in nearly a year as the Institute for Supply Management’s index of services slipped to 49.9 in May. Michael McKee reports on Bloomberg Television.
